title: How to mention your contributions as a freelancer in your resume - Quora

response.answer_text: I typically do not include it unless is truly exceptional. I have engaged in many freelance projects during my career and I’ve acquired a lot of experience due to these projects. However, only two stand out. Apps that acquired millions of users and made a huge impact on those users and I was a software development lead on those freelance projects, so it helps me sell myself as a leader/software manager. The only exception to my rule would be if you are completely new to the industry, and you literally have no experience then, by all means, include the freelance projects so that you can show the hiring manager that you are familiar with the software development lifecycle, meeting deadlines, delivering projects and deploying them to production.

Some people will just list themselves as Freelancer in the job title. So that’s one way to show you’re freelancing. An alternative to show you’ve done some freelancing is to have a bulleted statement with your qualifications summary or as an additional information section. Which way to go is a personal choice and a matter of best judgment. And yes, it is acceptable to use a job title that shows what kind of freelancing you’re doing. For example, Freelance Web Designer. It’s also a personal choice whether you want to provide some details about the kind of freelancing you’ve done or are currently doing. Some include details about their freelance activities. Others just want to get across they’re doing or have done freelance work and leave details out. One more way to handle things is to have a separate section for your freelance activities. So if you have several things to list and/or want to draw specific attention to this, then completely separating it out with its own section may be the right way to go. Again, this is a personal choice and a matter of best judgment.

As a freelancer, you’ve gained skills and experience that are just as valuable and valid as the ones learned in a more traditional workplace. As such, like other traditional experiences, you should state your freelance work under the Professional Experience section of your resume. What you must include here are your title or role that accurately reflects the work you’re doing; date range; projects you have worked on; accomplishments; and pretty much anything that relates to your competencies as a freelancer or an independent contractor. Complying with the basic rule of resume writing, experiences including freelance work, should be listed on your resume in reverse chronological order (newest on top) and in a consistent manner.

You can have a separate section detailing freelance assignments that you have worked upon in various time frames. You must mention there the kind of freelance works you have done and how well you performed in executing them. For example 'Overtook freelance assignment of social media marketing for a start-up and help them establish a strong social media presence.’

Hello, Essentially the same way you would list a normal position but with a few caveats. For example : Fiction Writer - Freelance | Company Name, City, WA Freelance Fiction Writer | Company Name, City, WA If you don’t have a business name exclude it. If you did it remotely, enter “Remote” for the location. I would also consider replacing the word freelancer with consultant or independent contractor as freelancer tends to have some negative associations. Finally, I would list (if possible) the names or business names of your clients to authenticate your freelancing claims. If you need further help writing your resume check out my book here. All the best, Dan

Everyone is a freelancer at the end of the day. Nobody owns anyone anymore. Job security is a fallacy, and you should be on your grind, even if you have a salary. That being said, I would put the projects on there instead of the fact that you’re a freelancer. Putting “freelancer” is the same as putting “human”.

freelancing is a work you do to earn money only not to show the knowledge you have that knowledge for which you are working to earn money for every order or service you deliver. you get an invoice for that that will be the proof of work done but you will not add these invoices in your CV you can only mention that i do freelancing in this this skills when the interviewer asks you about it. you can explain him orally or even show your works if he ask so

Thanks for your query. I would suggest that you don't need to add your freelance experience if it is not adding any value to your resume. Space is gold in a resume. You've maximum two pages to summarize all your skills and achievements with projects, education and professional summary. But if you're looking to add more to your resume then you can create a section for Additional Experience- where you could mention your freelance experience. I hope this will help you. All the best!

List your place as if it were work on your resume. Understand the job offer to which you apply. ... Think about using those skills to do freelance work. Change your curriculum — find the greatest accomplishments that come from freelancing.

An effective way to list freelance work on your resume is to simply state the projects you have undertaken, the period you worked on them as well as the field(s) you have worked on. Also, you might want to state the number of words you have translated. I suggest not to mention the company name(s) for confidentiality reasons, unless you are authorized to do so by your client.

You would list it just like any other employment entry. List your freelance work as ‘Independent Contractor’ and list your achievements as such.
Under work experience section, make a subsection of freelancing projects and mention the relevant details.
